Tube or Tubeless, which do you prefer & why? tnx
Only ever have tubes and not many Flats. And flat has been easy to change for me this far
data.author: Amanda Brandimore

data.text: following
data.author: Shelby Evers

data.text: I've only ever used tubes due to cost.
data.author: Natalie Stenger

data.text: Tubes filled with Stans. Just too easy and clean, and no you know whats in years. ü§ûü§ûü§û
data.author: Pedaling Pete

data.text: how often do you refill the tubes with stans? how many mL do you use per tube?
data.author: Trebor Notrab

data.text: I have 700 x 45's and fill with 4 oz each. Every 6 months or so I spin and listen to make sure I'm not overfilling, and if not, I add 2 oz thinned with 2 oz of water. I use this. for 9 bucks. The injector tube is very thin. I have to fill the injector without the tube, then attached the tube and inject. The valve remover is worth the 9 bucks.
data.author: Pedaling Pete

data.text: are you using a specific innertube to be filled with it or just any brand will do?
data.author: Trebor Notrab

data.text: Happens that I got the best deal on Continentals, with Shrader, but I do it on any and all the bikes I service for my friends and family. So far the only leaks it will not seal are major valve leaks right at the tube. I also run very good tires, or so I think. Schwalbe Greenguards, and Bontrager hard case 5 Ultimates.
data.author: Pedaling Pete

data.text: do you still patch the tube if the sealant can seal a large hole or just replace the whole thing?
data.author: Trebor Notrab

data.text: good thing i have bought the continentals with shrader valves. üòÅ
data.author: Trebor Notrab

data.text: I still patch If and when I find that they leaked. I can usually tell because I'm suddenly down a few pounds of pressure.
data.author: Pedaling Pete

data.text: that would be perfect. I really appreciate you helping me out. Thanks Pete. Have a safe ride always
data.author: Trebor Notrab

data.text: Thanks, Hope you have the luck I've had.
data.author: Pedaling Pete

data.text: Agree, this has worked for me also. I cut hole in tube, pour sealant in then patch.
data.author: Rick Twigg

data.text: Tubeless, smoother and can handle the rock or pot hole slam. Lighter too
data.author: Michelle Anne Trayer

data.text: The best tire for my road bike is a Rene Herse extralight Cayuse (700x26), but that tire was not designed to be set up tubeless. I use latex tubes and it feels like you're riding on a conveyor belt. The best tire for my gravel bike is a Rene Herse standard Snoqualmie (700x44) and its set up tubeless. Not having a tube needed for a tire that size saves a lot of weight and reduces rolling resistance. I haven't had a flat for the last 2k miles. The best tire for my touring bike is a Schwalbe Marathon Mondial (26 x 2.0) that I use with a tube but could be set up tubeless. Its durability and tread pattern are ideal for my type of touring. I run them with tubes because if I do have some tire/tube problems and there's not a bike store around, I can probably find what I need at Walmart.
data.author: Adam Tripp

data.text: Solid tubes. (No air or slime) stop-a-flat is the best brand. You will never have a flat, or need to change your tubes. Iv had the same tubes on my bike for 2 years and they are still working great. I ride 10 miles every day, on and off road. If you are looking for long term durability, stop-a-flat is the best option. All my friends use and recommend stop-a-flat.
data.author: Bob Brown

data.text: thank you for the info. I'll go check this one out.
data.author: Trebor Notrab

data.text: Mountain bike - Tubeless. All my other bikes I run tubesüëç
data.author: Bradly Chipman

data.text: my MTBs are all running tubeless. But for my touring/gravel bike, still getting ideas from you guys which one is best. Thank you for sharing
data.author: Trebor Notrab

data.text: I was going to switch my Gravel bike to tubeless, but (knock on wood) I never get any flats. I was always flatting on my mountain bike, that's why it's Tubeless.. Personally I find tubeless to be a pain in the buttüëç
data.author: Bradly Chipman

data.text: pain in the butt indeed ü§£ so messy & cost more. good thing i never had flats with my mtbs
data.author: Trebor Notrab

data.text: Tube & liner. No messy sealant. Even tubeless, you still have to carry a tube for emergencies, plus the sealant in yo-ur tire, so its actually heavier to travel that way.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: not true, use a dynaplug. Even sealant is 60gr.
data.author: Pieter Mels

data.text: Tubes for me
data.author: Dale Nimmo

data.text: tubes sealant is too messy and more tan not with road conditions and how much garbage is on them. I typically will get a big enough gash, that sealant wont help.
data.author: Robert Provenzano

data.text: Both. I ride with tubes on my touring bike and tubeless on my road bike.
data.author: Tom Etheridge

data.text: i am now observing my tires. I run tubeless up front and tubes in the rear. i'll test it tomorrow and see what happens üòÖ
data.author: Trebor Notrab

data.text: wow, and I thought I ran a diverse setup. I ride two different styles, road bike for speed and touring bike is slower and much heavier. Both are fun.
data.author: Tom Etheridge

data.text: it's super fun to ride a bike üòâ
data.author: Trebor Notrab

data.text: Tubeless. As a 200lb road rider, pinch flats were far too regular. Have not had a flat on tubeless that wasn't of my own making. Gravel bike came fully tubeless compatible, so went ahead there, then upgraded the road bike when building wheels for it. I still carry tubes as an emergency measure, just in case.
data.author: Simon Tomkins

data.text: I prefer tubes on my touring bike, which is a road bike. With GatorSkins, flats are a rarity. Zero on my first tour covering 5,169 miles over 3.5 months.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: : Ditto (y)
data.author: Boyet Dizon

data.text: that's amazing
data.author: Trebor Notrab

data.text: I feel my tires with concrete.
data.author: Steven Coleman

data.text: tar would be great ü§£
data.author: Trebor Notrab

data.text: I use tubes made for the desert where there is cactus spikes on the ground it‚Äôs been on my bike 3-4 years now and without flat
data.author: Yoh√§nan Sebastos

data.text: I have tubes on all my bikes. I usually get schwalbe tires or puncture resistant tires. I find tubes to be versatile. Say the tube is no good to use for your wheel, you can use the rubber to create bands/strips. If you need to tie down stuff.
data.author: Jerms Fisher

data.text: Tubes - easier to maintain thorough the year.
data.author: Tomasz Plasota

data.text: Tubes with Scwalbe durano double defence on my training/winter bike. Nearly 3 years of training in the winter without a visit from the p******* fairyüòÅ
data.author: Matt Plews

data.text: I prefer air in my tire
data.author: Tyler Bohlmeyer

data.text: Tubeless for the last 12,000 miles. I don't think I'll go back to tubes except as a temporary repair until I reach the next good bike shop. But if weight is unimportant to you then (heavy) puncture-proof tyres with tubes are a sensible choice too.
data.author: Michael Bryant

data.text: Tubeless
data.author: Ross Leahy

data.text: Tannus Armour tyre inserts.
data.author: Ian Stapo

data.text: seconded
data.author: Jon France

data.text: So one problem I have with tubeless is changing tyre pressure. Ride to the MTB park, let the tyres down and then ride around the park. Letting your tyres down from road pressure to off road pressure seems hard because the sealant wants to come out. Does anyone else have a solution to this. This is what stops me widely adopting tubeless in my MTB and slime in touring bikes.
data.author: Aaron Davis

data.text: stem up when dropping pressures, then only a tiny amount sprays out.
data.author: Jeff Burke

data.text: my tumbles tire leeked quite a bit, expecially at the valve. It seems that after encouraging it to leek and leaving the wheel to have a chance for the sealant to set and form a bond is the trick. I actually loosened the nut on the valve stem to encourage sealant to escape to form a seal.
data.author: Brian Alexander Langton

data.text: , my problem is that I want to let my tyres down at every visit to the MTB park, especially where I have ridden some distance to get there and therefore have wanted the tyres at road pressure to get there. The same with gravel riding on different bikes where I have had sealant in the tubes and want to let them down when I get to the gravel. Sealent comes out and makes a mess. Sealent just doesn‚Äôt seem to work (for me at least) letting tyres down.
data.author: Aaron Davis

data.text: Tubeless definitely ride nice and the bike I am on currently has them, and so it will remain. But I had a night mare getting tubeless to work on another bike and it cost a ridiculous amount of money, tape, valves, fluid, compression tank, no end of swearing. I think that's the nub of it great when they work, a nightmare when they do not. Tubeless advocates seldom mention the cost of tubeless or the need to top up the fluid. Myself mixed feelings, they are great when they work but tubes are so much simpler and cheaper.
data.author: Mick Hine

data.text: simplier & cheaper indeed
data.author: Trebor Notrab

data.text: Traditional tubes ... whip then out, check them over & repair, pop them back in, pump up
data.author: Danny Simmons

data.text: Ive never tried tubeless, but I do pretty well with tubes. I just bought the good glue on patches and they work well to repair a flat.
data.author: Beca Abood Morgan

data.text: Cycled over a rusty three inch nail pulled it out , five hundred kilometres later still riding my bike no issues
data.author: Karl Clark

data.text: Tubeless. We did 2000 km through the bush without a flat tyre. When we got home I washed the bikes and found three small trails of gunk on my back tyre. Gunk did the job.
data.author: David Thornbury

data.text: Running tubeless up front and tube in the rear b/c there is some defect in the tire and tubeless wouldn‚Äôt set up. Wish they were both tubeless.
data.author: Josh Simonds

data.text: TubULAR (not 'tubed' or tubeless, are my favourites!
data.author: Stuart Agutter

data.text: great question. until i use up my stock pile of tubes then i will consider switching.
data.author: Tee Cee

data.text: Unless they stop making tubes & they become unavailable, I'll never switch to tubeless. I have read hundreds of posts on the subject in numerous groups, and with tubeless there is near certainty that you will someday have a virtually irreparable flat. Tires are mission-critical, better to fix 100 flats than to have 1 that you cannot fix - on the side of the road, in the dark, in the rain, using the tools and supplies you have with you. Just my view, others may feel that the convenience of tubeless outweigh this fatal flaw, but I do not. However, everyone sets their own priorities, and that's fine. Ride what you want, how you want. Be happy.
data.author: Terry L. Manuel

data.text: tnx for sharing.
data.author: Trebor Notrab
